captions.text:
There are some words that just
doesn't belong together.
Salmon and ketchup.
DeLorean and handling.
Porsche and diesel.
That's right.

Porsche and that oily fraction
of crude that
doesn't want to ignite.

When Porsche said it was making
a diesel Panamera with

a tweaked Audi engine to boot,
I swear, Dr. Ferdinand
Porsche's grave [INAUDIBLE].

But the problem with having
deeply, deeply trenchant views

on stuff like diesel Porsches,
is that you set yourself up

for a massive fall if, for the
sake of argument, Porsche

makes a diesel and you
end up liking it.

Because that's what's
happened with me.
I'm spending--
I don't know--

3-4 months living with a
Panamera diesel, and I have to

say, it's extraordinarily
good.

It's so much better than I
thought it was going to be.

And it's so much nicer to live
with than I expected from my

experience on a first
drive last summer
when the car was launched.
Hmm.
Yes.

I've had to swallow
some pride.

But then again, not as bad as
Mr. Wiedeking, when he was the
boss of Porsche--

and I think it was the
facelift Boxster
launch back in 2002--

told me categorically there'll
be no diesel Porsches.
Well, here we are in one.

What's the Panamera like as
a big exec saloon car?

It's right on the sporty
side of exec.

That means that the ride
is quite firm.

This car is on steel springs,
not on air.

And it just changes direction
superbly.
You sit low.
The steering is fantastic.

I think it's the most impressive
big sports sedan
I've driven, really.
It's just excellent to be in.

A couple of other things you
need to know about the
Panamera diesel.

To start with, it may be an Audi
V6 turbo diesel, but I'm
barely aware of that fact.

It makes a nicer noise-- it
makes actually quite a
pleasant noise.

The throttle response
is better.
It just feels different.

Porsche have recalibrated
it and done it well.

They've taken the same old
ingredients and produced a
better food.

The other thing is the way that
it goes around corners.
It is supreme.
Long wheelbase, wide tracks.

It's a big car on UK roads, but
you can just steer it with
so much accuracy.

OK, it's quite firm, but it's
remarkably easy to thread,

and, I think, really
enjoyable.
This car feels rear driven.
Not many turbo diesels do.

So if you want to, you can
neutralize the car mid-corner
with a load of gas.
It's impressive.

So much more impressive than
perhaps some people think.
Now what about the looks.

It's not for me to judge
the way anything looks.

Look at the way I
present myself.
I just don't care.

But I like the look
of the Panamera.

I like the fact that it's
completely different.

I think it's really cool
from the front.

Neil probably brought this bit
out, because he thinks the

Panamera looks absolutely
dreadful, so he'll
lose it in the edit.

And most of the British
population seems to
disagree with me.

But I really like the
way it looks.

Now, the main problem with the
Panamera diesel is the

perception of the car's
performance.

There can be no queries and
quibbles about the way it goes

about its performance
on the road.

This powertrain is
exceptional.

Yes, it's the Audi V6 turbo
diesel, and it's the
[INAUDIBLE]
high-speed gearbox.

But the management of torque,
gear ratios, and performance,
and most of all, refinement.
This car is so refined.

That is just extraordinary, and
I defy anyone to not think
it's incredibly refined.

Now, the bone of contention
is the amount of
performance it offers.

So I'm referring directly
back to the thread on
piston heads actually.

I wrote that I was driving the
car, and a load of people came

on and just said, it's rubbish,
it's not fast enough
to be a Porsche.
It's just not fast enough.
Full stop.

Well, today I'd like to
answer a couple of
those points really.

On the one hand, what is fast
enough for a road car?

That's what comes out
of the discussion.

The other thing is, what's fast
enough for a car to wear
a Porsche badge?

That's an interesting
notion as well.

But also, is this car fast
enough as a turbo diesel
saloon car?

I mean, some people might
think it isn't.

But everything subjectively that
I've done in this car--

I've driven it to Stuttgart
and back.

I've done 5-6,000 miles
in it already.

Every minute I've spent in it,
it's felt fast enough, but
people don't believe me.

People just say I'm saying
that for the sake of it.
Well, I'm not.
Honestly.
I drive lots of cars.
Lots of really fast cars.

But this one, for the road,
feels just right to me.
Just right.

But does anyone wait for me to
really prove that to you?

And that's to come to
a proving ground.

Put some timing gear on it, or
rather use Dynolicious on my

iPhone, which is
just wonderful.
And then run some numbers.

So we're going to run it against
the clock on the

standing quarter to see how fast
it is and then stick it

on the high speed bowl
at Millbrook.

Because that's the best
proving ground in
the UK, isn't it?
So yeah.

Panamera diesel goes for
a figuring session.

It's a bit like taking a
slightly fat person to the
beach, isn't it?
You shouldn't really do it.

But the fact is, I need
to prove this.

I can't just justify the
Panamera diesel subjectively.

I need to give you
some numbers.

So here we are at Millbrook
on the Mile Straight.

I always get a bit misty eyed
when I come here, because this

is where I started out doing
this car testing game.
[INAUDIBLE]

car road test tests, come up
here once a week and see how
fast cars would go.

Rather a simple exercise, but
one I always found endlessly

enjoyable and from which I
learned to attach a certain

amount of importance to the raw
data that a car produces.

60 maybe even 30, 100 standing
quarters, all of
that sort of stuff.

Now driving this car,
subjectively it feels
absolutely fast enough for me.
OK?
But I've said that.

And subjectivity
isn't something
that you need to believe.

However, if I do a run in this
car on the Mile Straight,

hopefully we can prove
to you that it's
actually quite quick.

I've got Dynolicious plugged
in here on my iPhone.
Very accurate.
So I press Test Start.

We'll wind it off the line
a little bit, and
then see what happens.
It still feels fast to me.

Even in a straight line at
a great big test track.
Through 60, easy.
Through 80.

Now then, what do we match
this car against?

Because what I find interesting
is everyone says
this car isn't fast enough.

But what really is
fast enough?

Because that's just popped in
a 6.9-second run there.

And that wasn't an
ideal launch.

It's also telling me that the
standing quarter was completed

in 15.2 seconds at a terminal
speed of 96 miles an hour.

But if I told you that earlier
a couple of times it did 14.9

seconds at a terminal speed
of-- wait for it--

99.1 miles an hour, does that
make this car not fast enough?

Because one of my benchmark
references for a car of this

type is the original
E60 535d BMW.

And that car would record 6
seconds dead to 60 miles an

hour and 15 seconds
dead to 100.

Well, this car will
do about 6.56.
So round it up 6.6 to 60.

And it was saying it does 99.1
miles an hour after a standing
stop in 14.9 seconds.

That must mean that it's doing
around 15.5 to a 100,

somewhere between 15
and 16 seconds.

So it's within a second from
0 to a 100 over 535d.

That has to make this car
fast enough, doesn't it?
I mean tell me I'm wrong.

And how fast does a
car need to be?

So Porsche claims that this car
will do 150 miles an hour.

So we know that it will already
get to 100 miles an
hour pretty quickly.

So why does it need to
go more than 150?
I don't know.

I mean, given that it will
actually average 40 miles to

the gallon when you're
going quick.

Anyhow, let's clock it and
see what it'll do.

We're up to a 100 miles
an hour now.
Indicated 120.
144 indicated.

Feels like it's sort of
had enough there.
146 still.

Not sure of the wind
direction.

Wind plays a big part
on this bowl.
Now it's still creeping up.
150 indicated.

That's still only 145,
148, 149 on the GPS.
So that's creeping up now.
And that's 149 on the GPS.
148, 149 it's averaging.

That's dead impressive because
that means that on the flat,

this is doing 155, 156
real miles an hour.

And it feels pretty
unruffled to me.

Now in what world do we live
where that is not considered
to be fast enough?
I just find it quite bizarre.

Now, this is right up there
with the most pointless

exercises I've been
involved with.

We're at the Millbrook
Handling Circuit.

Also known as the place where
we put space savers on a C63

AMG back at the beginning of
the year, if I remember.

Why am I driving a Panamera
diesel out here?

Well, this is a Porsche,
isn't it?

It's supposed to be
a sports saloon.
Let's see what it's like.

I think it's pretty good,
so I still can't quite
believe it's a diesel.
I mean, it feels [INAUDIBLE]
fast to me.
[INAUDIBLE] here.
The gearbox is good.
It'll actually [INAUDIBLE]
downshift for you.
Loads of torque.

Up the back here, it's
fast, fast, fast.

It's flat once you [INAUDIBLE]
through the direction change.
Really good.

I mean, this is a standard
car on steel suspension.

It doesn't have air
suspension.

And it's dead impressive
because of it.
Wow.
I love the way it steers.

I just think it has the
best steering of
any big saloon car.

And you can really feel
that it's rear driven.

It's not giving me big
oversteer, but the steering's

uncorrupted and I've
got this nice push.

So when I throttle, I can
control the front of the car,

and it's not understeering
at all.
And it's really strolling on.
It's quite quick.
God.
Do you know what?

If it's surprising on the
road, it's even more
surprising here.

So what we have here is a
four-seat saloon car that

weighs 1,900 kilograms, but will
cover null to 60 in about

6.6 seconds, 100 miles an hour
in around about 15.5 seconds.

And on the Millbrook bowl, it'll
do over a 150 miles an

hour, which we know means
nearly 160 on the flat.

And yet, when you're not on it,
this car will average 45

miles to the gallon
on a long journey.
Do you know what?

If that's the blend of talents
that occurs when Porsche makes

a diesel, then I can
live with it.

Which is good, because
I am living with it.

title: Resident Evil? Diesel power in a Porsche Panamera - /CHRIS HARRIS ON CARS

comments.text:
Chris, yes it is fast enough (at least for me...).
I had a 535d for a few years. Now I have a Panamera diesel which feels 
faster than the the bmw. The torque is incredible. Build quality is 
excelent. Overall it´s the best car I've ever owned. I had a few fast cars 
(Z4 35i, E90 M3, jaguar XK, bmw 535d, megane RS etc...). None of them comes 
even close to the Porsche Panamera.
Thank you for your videos. I really enjoy them.﻿

comments.author: sam alame

comments.text:
Yes but "why"? Why would someone buy a Porsche diesel if it lacks in 
performance and it's engine is only good for MPG? If someone have a 
Panamera "money" then he does not need to worry about fuel consumption. If 
someone want this ugly big P. then he should go for the full performance 
turbo version, not some diesel with Audi (VW developed) engine. At the end, 
there is a much better, refined Italian 4 door supercar called Maserati 
Quattroporte, and you don't have to care, because it is a true petrol car, 
not some common rail diesel with turbo to increase power output.﻿
comments.author: Rejected Beats

comments.text:
+bighands69 Yeah, but I am shure that Ferdinand Porsche never wanted to 
make a  "affordable family car", and that is caused by capitalism a need to

There is so much good cars on the market for £150,000 or less. If that is

family car.
comments.author: Rejected Beats

comments.text:
+Rejected Beats
Porsche Panamera, Macan and Cayenne are affordable family cars. There are 
men out there who could justify one of these to their family but could 
never justify a £150,000 911. 

It is that simple. Yes they could afford a Boxer or Cayman but they are

comments.author: bighands69

comments.text:
+John Amutenya Yes, but in he 80's Porsche and Ferrari cost almost the 
same, and they both were a cool cars. I still like and respect 911, and 
it's heritage, but I can't give a name or badge of Porsche to something 
that is ugly, has 4 dors and diesel engine in it. It is just so wrong.
"VW owns Porsche, not the other way around. " Are you sure? Those are 
owners of Volkswagen Auto Group listed by share:
Porsche Automobil Holding SE (50.7%)[3]
State of Lower Saxony (20%)
Qatar Holding LLC (17%)
Capital Group Companies (4.097% participation, 5.6% voting rights)
And if we search for more information, we will found that the founder of 
the Porsche Automobil Holding SE is Ferdinand Porsche and that it is 
founded in 1931. in Stuttgart. Now the chairman of Porsche SE is Wolfgang 
Porsche. If we know that the Volkswagen is a member of a Volkswagen Auto 
Group, can we conclude who is the owner of the Volkswagen? For me it is a 
Porsche SE.
comments.author: Rejected Beats

comments.text:
+Rejected Beats Porsche isn't Ferrari. Porsche can't sell a 911 GT3 for 
$400,000. Ferrari can sell as similar performing car for 3x the money. The 
911 wasn't making much money, the 959 cost a ton of money and didn't make 
much back, same with Carrera GT, same with their racing programs. If it 
weren't for Cayennes and Panameras. We would not have 918s and 919 race 
cars. Ferrari make a profit from racing. VW owns Porsche, not the other way 
around. Porsche needs to make a certain amount of money each year or 
programs like the 918, GT3, 911 Turbo, 919 Hybrid will all be cut.
comments.author: John Amutenya

comments.text:
+jimfastlane28 I did not noticed that the Ferrari need some Diesel or SUV 
vehicle to made 458 or California. And they are selling only 7.000 cars in 
one year, which makes it so exclusive and desirable. Porsche was exclusive 
and desirable car, but now it is so commercial and that reduces it's value.
I don't think that they really need that cars for money or profit, 
because Porsche Automobil Holding SE is owner of the Volkswagen Group AG, 
so they can make enough money to make coll cars like 911. Those cars exists 
for only one purpose, and that is profit, without much care for heritage of 
true Porsche and buyers of those cars.
comments.author: Rejected Beats

comments.text:
+Rejected Beats The reason Porsche makes the Panamera diesel and others 
like Cayenne (their biggest selling vehicle) is to sell more cars so that 
they can still make stuff like the new 911 GT3. If Porsche hadn't made what 
so many people call the poor man's Porsche, the Boxster (still the best car 
in its class), the fact is that Porsche wouldn't be around to make any cars 
at all. The Panamera D isn't for everyone but if you listen to Chris Harris 
and other reviews, its a damn good car that happens to give good 
performance while its also able to average 40mpg which is what you want in 
an everyday car.
comments.author: jimfastlane28

comments.text:
+Oğuzhan Alemdar I live in Europe, and I know what you can buy on European 
market. I just want to say, if I am rich, and want to buy a Porsche, that 
would be just 911 turbo, not some 4 door, and not with diesel engine. But 
Porsche became almost commercial car, under infulence of VW Auto Group 
ownership. Now they want to make a Bentley SUV with diesel engine. Why? 
Just to sell more cars, and to destoy the heritage and history of the 
legend. Diesel is good in small and reasonable priced cars, but Porsche 
(once a ture German car legend, 16 times winner of the 24 Hours of Le Mans) 
with diesel in it... it just not works for me.
comments.author: Rejected Beats

Well today's diesels are very efficient, smooth and got performance. These

expensive and expencive every year

comments.text: by all means, Porsche... make us a Station Wagon, while you're at it!!!!﻿
comments.author: Joao Marques

comments.text:
The only "resident evil" is the Jeremy Clarkson-induced bias which seems to 
enslave and mesmerise the British car lover. I salute you, Chris, for 
following your own mind and not being intimidated by popular opinion. A 
reviewer shouldn't be a bleating sheep, merely following the flock. It 
takes guts to give an honest, objective opinion. And that's why you remain 
my favourite critic and reviewer of cars- by far!﻿

I have a bit of a soft spot for the Panamera - I thought it was ugly too 
until I saw one in person. Having said that, I'm not interested in an oil 
burning version - 0-100 in well over 6 seconds and standing 1/4 in around 
15 seconds really is too slow for something so expensive that you can't 
really do much to improve. I'm too used to having something vastly faster. 
 So yeah, for me personally, Chris is wrong.﻿
comments.author: Matthew Sharpe

comments.text:

For 99% of families the diesel Panamera is fast enough and for those that

and you may love the Falcon.
comments.author: bighands69

comments.text:

comments.author: Jack Toff

comments.text:
I agree with everything except the part of doing nothing to improve the 
horsepower ratings. The problem lies with doing it fuel efficiently. It's 
already turbocharged and has a much higher compression ratio than gas being 
it doesn't have spark plugs. To increase power you add air (psi of boost) 
and fuel. A diesel, unlike gas, will continue to produce power running a 
very rich fuel to air ratio. This excess fuel however will come out of the 
pipe as soot and ruin your emissions. The soot, however doesn't go into the 
air but falls to the ground. Things like egr and def prevent any of these 
emissions even though they don't go into the air.

Point being: Upgrade boost (turbo), upgrade fuel (injectors), and get a 
tune to put it all together and you'll have your hp along with much more 
torque.

My experience lies in american diesel truck motors (duramax, powerstroke, 
cummins) so while still applicable, these engines aren't an expertise of 
mine.
comments.author: Tristan Patterson

comments.text:
+bighands69 Absolutely, everyone has different requirements - I don't doubt 
that you'd get a lot of enjoyment out of one if you do buy it, it's just 
not for me .  Not that I could afford one anyway, we only have space and 
budget for 2 cars, so my wife has the super practical Toyota SUV (which she 
loves anyway) and I have an Aussie Ford Falcon Turbo - which isn't too 
impractical other than the bad economy, but given the power it has it's not 
even too hard on fuel.
comments.author: Matthew Sharpe

comments.text:
There are people out there that could be buying a similar type of diesel 
for the same money as the Panamera and they would be happy with the speed. 

If you are not happy with the speed then you would go for the likes of a 
Cayman or 911 but depending on your budget. Me and my wife want a new 
family car and we are considering the Panamera Diesel. My sports car is a 
RS5 and we have a Toyota for a family car already that we are going to 
keep. 

There are many people out there like me who want a nice family sports car 
and there are many options and Porsche is one of those option which it was 
not 10 years ago.

comments.text:
modern diesel's are great. i drive a merc e350 cdi convertible and it does

comments.author: Nunzio Amitrano

comments.text:
I became a big believer in diesels after trying the VW v6 TDI in their Audi 
line.  V8 torque with hybrid fuel mileage?  Yes please.﻿
comments.author: Wolvesq

comments.text: 05:24 That is all. :-)﻿
comments.author: Frankus Lee

comments.text: But does it smoke like a diesel?﻿
comments.author: PvM Sly

comments.text:
Big diesels are quick. The A5 3.0tdi Quattro sport is one of the fastest 
cars I've driven in the real world. 0-60 5.9 seconds and feels like it 
could sail past 155 without the limiter. It's spookily quite to and returns 
40mpg easily. ﻿
comments.author: Ben Rollings

comments.text:
6.5 sec? I think the latest one is around 6 dead. Thats pretty bloody fast 
for a big diesel. Fastest car I owned(10 yrs ago) was a pre cat Maser 222e 
(5.6 to 60) and that was plenty.﻿
comments.author: fish fingers

comments.text: hahaha cheeky pom﻿
comments.author: David Zhang

comments.text:
Porsche should have the new Diesel S engine in the Panamera, 385 bhp, 850 
nm.﻿
comments.author: PorscheSweden

comments.text:
And yes, sure it's fast enough. 6.5 sec? That's fast enough to push you far 
back into the seat. It's faster than any hot hatchback for fuck sakes, it's 
faster than a Golf GTI, Megane RS, Focus ST...and does anyone ever go 
inside a hot hatchback and says "man, its too slow"? Nope...haven't met one 
yet, people usually go crazy about how fast they feel. And it being a 
diesel, full acceleration doesn't show the half of it's performance. 
Diesels are about in-gear performance from low and mid revs, not 0-60. Take 
a petrol engine with 6.5 to 60, and this diesel will feel and will be MUCH 
faster in gear, during overtaking, accelerating at high speeds, 
accelerating onto the highway, etc...pretty much real world stuff. And the 
low pitched noise that it makes adds to the sensation of acceleration, 
because you simply aren't used to be pushed forwards at such pace without 
the engine screaming at high revs like in petrol cars.﻿
comments.author: derbigpr500

comments.text:
Fully agree and I'd add that the in gear power is largely down to the high 
torque diesel engines make at low revs.
comments.author: Cameron Coe

comments.text:
The funniest thing is, it's usually the americans who claim certain cars 
are not fast enough, or that diesels are slow or not good enough, because 
in Europe we definitely don't think that, and sales statistics show that. 
And the reason it's funny is because they really have no experience to talk 
about either of those two things. They don't have experience in driving 
fast (since they have ridiculous speed limits and shittiest traffic culture 
in the world that makes you wanna shoot 5 people per minute while driving 
on their clogged up highways), or driving a car with a diesel engine.  If 
diesels are fast enough for european roads, where people on average drive 
much, much faster than in the US, then they're sure as hell fast enough in 
the USA where most people slug along at 50 or 60 mph in their automatics 
while drinking coffe on really crappy highways or freeways with nowhere 
near the flatness or quality of surface as on the european highways.﻿
comments.author: derbigpr500

comments.text:
+René Gerritsen You have a point when talking about range. But the torque 
difference is not as huge as it used to be. A couple of years ago most 
petrol engines where naturally aspirated but now they they are all turbo 
charged. Besides, no matter how much torque a 1.6 or 2.0 diesel engine 
produces (and after all, those are the ones we buy), you can have a petrol 
engine (bigger admittedly) that produces bigger figures). But why don't we 
do that, because they are more expensive to run. And we are back again at 
the running costs issue.
The fact of the matter is that if petrol didn't start getting as expensive 
as it did let's say 30 years ago, we wouldn't have gone the diesel route.
The reason in the US they believe diesel is for trucks is because they 
never had the need to drive diesel in cars. in Europe, we didn't really 
have the choice.
comments.author: Pieter De Greef

comments.text:
+Pieter De Greef Diesel has other advantages than just the price. Petrol 
cars don't get as far on one tank of fuel as diesel cas do and once you are 
used to that, you really hate the crappy mileage you get with petrol cars 
(says the guy driving 2 petrol cars ;)). But nevertheless I agree with 
derbigpr500: in Europe we have many more diesel powered cars and especially 
the Germans build some very fast ones. Mercedes, Audi and BMW have all 
built fast diesel cars, V8's with so much torque that you can drive off in 
any gear, etc... In the US the general feeling is that diesels are for 
trucks and petrol engines are for cars. That has nothing to do with running 
costs :)
comments.author: René Gerritsen

comments.text:
+derbigpr500 Thats bullshit. We in Europe don't drive diesel because they 
are fast of good enough. We buy them because they are cheaper to run. Thats 
it. If petrol was as cheap over here as in in other continents or it 
wouldn't be taxed as much, we too would be driving bigger petrol engines. 
Don't bullshit anyone by telling it's not true.
comments.author: Pieter De Greef

comments.text: +Chase Kubikinikinik That would be blue smoke...
comments.author: René Gerritsen

comments.text: +NewStarWaterCube unless the white stuff he is referring to is burnt oil...
comments.author: Chase Kubikinikinik

comments.text:
+Azaan Habib Thats not true Azaan
The white "stuff" as you call it is almost just water.

The black diesel smoke is quite toxic and not really got for plants.
cancerogen ;)
comments.author: NewStarWaterCube

comments.text:
'Diesels are worst for the air.' That's not true, the black stuff you see 
is unhurt fuel which then helps plants grow. The White stuff that comes out 
of petrol engines goes into the atmosphere.
comments.author: no name

comments.text:
I wouldn't say that highways in the US are crappy and bumpy. In the big 
cities like New York, LA or even Denver and Miami, Denver was ok though, 
you can have some bumpier roads. Howver out of the cities they have many 
perfect roads.
comments.author: Smita

comments.text:
diesel or petrol it doesn't matter, in the end they will both kill you , 
just pick your poison and be happy. The main reason diesel is more popular 
is because people are cheap, the torque is nice but you get good torque in 
a modern petrol engine so mpg figures is probably the main reason people 
choose diesel. The new petrol engines from Audi and Bmw have huge usable 
power bands max torque from about 1500-4500 and max power from 4500 to 
redline.
comments.author: e3446

comments.text: +Belgae ^ forgot to tag you
comments.author: Chase Kubikinikinik

comments.text:
The price of diesel fuel here in America is significantly higher than even 
premium gasoline. Yes, I'm serious about it burning cleaner. Diesel 
particulates are nowhere near as harmful as the gasses produced through the 
combustion of gasoline. If you don't believe me, then do some research. 
Diesels are also much more efficient. If you can show me a 1100HP gas 
vehicle with 6.6L of displacement that can achieve 30+ MPG then please do 
share.
comments.author: Chase Kubikinikinik

comments.text:
+Chase Kubikinikinik please don't tell me you're actually serious about 
diesel being cleaner than gas....(ofcourse diesel are growning in 
popularity the prices of diesel fuel are usually lower)
comments.author: Belgae

comments.text:
+Belgae and last time i checked, diesels are growing in popularity, not 
decreasing.
comments.author: Chase Kubikinikinik

comments.text:
the air leaving the tailpipe of a new diesel truck with emissions controls 
is cleaner than the air going into the intake. Either way, diesel fumes 
(whether you see it or not) are cleaner than that of gasoline cars. Diesel 
fumes are nowhere near as harmful as gasoline fumes. Im not saying that 
diesel fumes wont cause cancer, but gasoline fumes can kill you if you 
breathe it in for too long, not give you a disease. Just because you can 
see the fumes, doesnt mean its worse.
comments.author: Chase Kubikinikinik

comments.text:
diesel cars won't be arround much longer even though they are getting 
cleaner every year you can't get rid of the soot particles (now so small 
that they don't drop on the ground and pollute our drinking water and such 
but stay in the air allowing us to breath it in and giving us cancer) 
diesel is very polluting and will be removed from normal cars in the next 
decennia
comments.author: Belgae

comments.text: my f250 diesel is faster than this... it runs a 13.8 1/4 mile
comments.author: Chase Kubikinikinik

comments.text:

:)
comments.author: Jo Kommentaah

comments.text:
+Jo Kommentaah
Yep.  Needs a serious reform, especially knowing the fact that once you get 
your full license, the only thing you have to worry about is just paying to 
renew it ever 10-20 years.
But,
it ain't gonna happen anytime soon.
comments.author: Akira Kawamoto/Ishikawa Masaki

comments.text:
+Akira Kawamoto/Ishikawa Masaki I knew the drivers test was a joke in the 
US but not that it is so much of a joke.. omg. If you ask me they seriously 
need to reform that.
comments.author: Jo Kommentaah

comments.text:
+Jo Kommentaah
You are pretty much right.  In my state, you start off with a permit at 15 
which just cost $7 I think and you don't even need to prove that you can 
drive.  Then you got the test which you can take at 15.5 (years old, so 
after 6 months), which is another $30 I think (i forgot how it fully cost, 
but it ain't expensive at all).  You don't even have to go through the 
permit when you hit 18 years old, so you can skip the driving classes and 
driving time.  The driving age however when you first start varies from 
state to state though.

I can't completely talk about the taxes, but I do know that it's WAY 
cheaper here, especially with higher mileaged cars.  In the case of 
accidents, it's just about the same reasons.  However, people like to blame 
speed and not the drivers themselves lacking complete control over the car.
comments.author: Akira Kawamoto/Ishikawa Masaki

comments.text: I don't wear a helmet on the Autobahn - am I crazy or what? ;)﻿

comments.text:
I thought the title said Resident Evil because Chris was going to recommend 
it for the zombie apocalypse. Anyway. . .

Torquey engines make sense in luxury cars, regardless of whether they're

important bit. I feel like they could have gone one up and rammed some more 
power in though.﻿

Porsches, now I love them!﻿

+Kenjohn Quintero That's impressive! Particularly when you consider the 
vehicle weighs in at over 3,000lbs. Who says Porsche performance and diesel 
economy don't mix? It looks to me like Porsche has made a sports car 
(sports saloon) with the handling and road holding intact, with the added 
bonus of diesel fuel economy. I can certainly live with that. :) If only it 
were sold here in the USA, I'd take it for a test drive.

handling characteristics Porsche is known for, but now you'd have fuel 
economy as well.﻿

comments.text:
No, You're right. We're all different. Me for one thinks the best looking 
cayenne was the first incarnation but only the turbo S version, and it was 
a capable vehicle. 5200 lbs towing capability, 4.8 0-60, 5 person carrying 
capacity and true off-road capabilty given what a set of tires that could 
take a nearly 3 ton car 4.8 to 60 could do. And everyone thinks it's ugly. 
So you have a point. But seriously though, if a prius is hideous, then what 
is that new fiat abarth 500?
comments.author: KHYANDER

comments.text:
Sorry Khyander, I think you missed my point. Beauty is in the eye of the 
beholder. I think the Panamera is a beautiful car but it's my opinion and 
for everyone that thinks like me there are a dozen that think the opposite 
- my point is, who cares..? I don't buy a car that I think you will find 
attractive and I'm pretty sure you won't care what I think. The fact is 
that the Panamera is a hugely competent car by any objective measure. P.S I 
think the Prius is hideous :-)
comments.author: Tony27nine

comments.text:
So as with a select handful of great driving cars, why do they disregard 
the, "LOOKS NICE OR AT LEAST NOT HIDEOUS" box. At the end of the day you 
buy bmws, benzs and porsches to impress. For all the boxes you ticked, a 
prius, then, is a pretty great car in your opinion. Porsche pretty much 
said "we're gonna design an ugly car and see how many people deny the fact 
that it's ugly or say they like the design".
comments.author: KHYANDER

comments.text: Awesome video!
comments.author: VossenWheels

comments.text:
Not sure why everyone thinks that their opinion about its looks is worth 
sharing. If you don't like it don't buy it. For me I've driven Boxters, 
Caymans, 911s, Cayennes, Lotus Evoras, Jaguars etc etc, The Panamera is the 
first Porsche that doesn't feel like a weekend toy for these having a 
mid-life crisis. It's got space, four doors, incredible fuel economy, good 
performance for a 3 litre diesel. That ticks an awful lot of boxes. The 911 
is small, impractical, only two seats, is a hard ride..
comments.author: Tony27nine

Better in what respect? The Panamera has better steering but more 
importantly the Panamera is just built to a higher standard and also more 
reliable than ANY VW product. There's a reason the V6 Panamera is a $80k 
car and the V6 Audi A7 is a $60k car. That's a big price difference and it 
has to do with build quality. Porsche doesn't cut any corners
comments.author: Liftedview

comments.text:
See I love that "best of both worlds" thing... My 335d is a few years old, 
but if I take it easy, I can get about 40 mpg (and that is US gallons, not 
imperial). RENNtech did their magic on it (from 265 hp, 425 torque to 346 
hp, 480 torque), and after a suspension upgrade from Summit Racing in 
McDonough racing, it handles nearly as well as my M3... and in the 
mountains it is more fun! That torque makes mountain roads giggleworthy. It 
is a very different experience, but not a bad one...
comments.author: lasourisaboyante

comments.text:
Love the diesel... I have a heavily tuned 335d, and it is a monster. I 
think the panamera is beautiful from the front only... Every time I see one 
it just sets my teeth on edge a bit... I don't think it is hideous. But it 
isn't compelling.
